block.p: TV Confession in Iran At Jew's Espionage Trial The first of 13 Jewish men charged with spying went on trial in Shiraz, and Iranian television showed him making an admission that he had spied for Israel. The public confession came after the government refused to allow family members, human rights groups or the public to witness the opening of the trial.

Few Takers on China Visit Only two congressmen undecided on whether to vote to give China permanent normal trade relations accepted an administration invitation to let a Cabinet officer lead them on a trip to China to gauge trade and human rights conditions.

European Opposes U.S. Plan The foreign policy chief for the European Union, Javier Solana, said European officials were concerned about possible damage that the Clinton administration's plan for a missile defense system could do to Europe's security ties with the United States.

May Day Mass With the Pope Pope John Paul II, pre-empting the trade unions' traditional hold on May 1, presided over a workers' rally that combined a solemn Catholic Mass with a raucous rock concert dedicated to third world debt relief. But the day was less about the Vatican or pop music than about the changes it showed taking place in Italy.

Dispute on Red Cross Symbols Concern is spreading among international relief organizations that the American Red Cross may be on the verge of withdrawing from the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies because the umbrella organization has not agreed to admit an Israeli contingent under a Star of David flag.

Philippines Hostages Examined A doctor made the first visit to a group of 21 hostages held by armed rebels of the Islamic separatist group Abu Sayyaf. The hostages were suffering from hunger and diarrhea and some pleaded for water, as 50 to 70 rebels guarded the area. On a nearby island, another group of Abu Sayyaf rebels escaped with their 27 hostages when government troops overran their mountain base over the weekend, the military said.

Turkey Leader Lacks Votes Parliament failed for a second time to muster the two-thirds vote necessary to elect Ahmet Necdet Sezer, the reformist candidate for president favored by the leaders of all five parties, although Mr. Sezer finished far ahead of other candidates, with 314 votes. The next ballot is set for Friday; in that round, just a simple majority of 276 will be necessary.
Devils Lead Series, 2-1 The Devils beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5-1, in Game 3 of their five-of-seven-game playoff series.

Some Big Corporations Are Forsaking Soft Money Soft-money donations are on a pace to set a record, even though many big corporations have stopped making them because executives are disillusioned with the process and feel there are better ways to spend their companies' money and still stay politically involved. But other corporate interests, senior executives and unions are increasing their unrestricted gifts to political parties.

McCain-Gore Meeting Senator John McCain and Vice President Al Gore met for 20 minutes on Sunday. Mr. Gore said they discussed changing campaign financing, Mr. McCain's signature issue and one that Mr. Gore is also advancing. Mr. McCain is to meet with Gov. George W. Bush next week.

Document Request Rebuffed The White House said it would invoke executive privilege and lawyer-client privilege, as it told the House Government Reform Committee that it would not surrender some documents subpoenaed in an inquiry about missing e-mail messages. The action prompted an angry reply by the committee's chairman, Dan Burton.

Challenging Asylum Case Elian Gonzalez was pressured by ''distant'' relatives to sign a political asylum claim that he neither wanted nor understood, a lawyer for his father said in federal court papers.

Ruling on Retroactive Law The Supreme Court overturned a Texas man's sex abuse conviction on the ground that a change in state law had made it easier for the prosecution to prove its case than at the time the crime was committed.

Judge Mediates Settlement Lawyers said a tentative settlement had been reached in a 16-year-old case involving accusations that Baltimore public schools had woefully neglected physically and mentally disabled students. The settlement was reached through the mediation of a federal judge, a procedure thought to have been used only once before, and then unsuccessfully, in the Microsoft antitrust case.

Retiring 6.2% of National Debt The government said it would pay off $216 billion of the $3.5 trillion national debt by Sept. 30, the end of the fiscal year. In February, the projection was $167 billion. The Treasury secretary said the bigger payment resulted from the booming economy and a growth in tax revenue.

State Challenges U.S. Law In Bid for Cleaner Air The Legislature gave final passage to a bill intended to reduce air pollution drifting into New York from coal-burning power plants in the Midwest and South. The measure would stop New York companies from keeping money they make by selling pollution credits, earned by cleaning their own smokestacks, to major polluters elsewhere. The action is the first by a state that directly challenges a major provision of the Federal Clean Air Act of 1990.

Postponing 'Monologues' Role Donna Hanover will not take the lead in ''The Vagina Monologues'' on May 30 because of ''family circumstances.'' Her husband, Mayor Giuliani, has disclosed he has prostate cancer.

Catskills Casino Plan Park Place Entertainment signed an option to buy Kutsher's Country Club, the oldest resort in the Catskills, to create an entertainment and gambling complex that would be owned by the St. Regis Mohawks.
Pham Van Dong An early revolutionary who became premier of North Vietnam after independence from France in 1954 and head of the government of all Vietnam from 1976 to 1987, he was 94.
David Mahoney Sometimes described as the foremost lay advocate of research into the brain, he was 76.
Roots of the Human Family Tree Geneticists tracing the DNA patterns found in people throughout the world have identified lineages descended from 10 sons of a genetic Adam and 18 daughters of Eve.

Time Warner-ABC Dispute Time Warner Cable removed ABC television stations from cable systems it runs in seven cities serving 3.5 million homes, in a dispute with ABC's parent, Walt Disney, over fees for Disney cable channels.

Actors in Commercials Strike The Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists told their members not to work on television and radio commercials until an agreement was reached with advertisers.

Microsoft on Counterattack Microsoft plans to ask the judge in its antitrust case for broad access to government records and for permission to summon witnesses, in arguing against the government's proposal to break up the company.
New Long-Distance Plan Bell Atlantic is expected to introduce a calling plan today offering long-distance interstate calls for 8 cents a minute at any time, without monthly fees or minimum charges.
A European Exchange Merger The London and Frankfurt stock exchanges are expected to announce a merger tomorrow.
